newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - February 12.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - February 12.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Wednesday.
- Radical new measures to tackle child pornography, including its use on the internet, are to be introduced in the Irish parliament within weeks.
- Speculation is growing that Irish interest rates may fall by as much as half a percentage point to keep the pound within its limits in the Exchange Rate Mechanism.

- The correct use of new agents to control the HIV virus should make it possible to convert the deadly infection into a chronic disease, an international AIDS expert told a meeting in Dublin. - An Irish priest was in intensive care on Tuesday after he was stabbed in the back at his church in north London as he was making a cup of tea for a parishioner.
- Sterling continued its powerful rise on foreign exchange markets on Tuesday, touching a 52-month high against the D-Mark.
- Embarrassed opposition leader Bertie Ahern on Tuesday night ordered an ethics crackdown on his Fianna Fail politicians hours after a party councillor was convicted of an 84,000 Irish pound fraud.
- Irish agriculture minister Ivan Yates will move on Wednesday to introduce further new curbs to prevent food compounds for cattle being infected with meat and bone-meal.
- A report has identified over 500 million Irish pounds worth of new business potential for Irish sub-supply companies to the chemical, pharmaceutical and healthcare industry.
- Ireland's top 20 gang bosses face multi-million pound tax demands as part of the Irish government's crusade against organised crime.
- The British national anthem God Save the Queen is to be played before Saturday's rugby international between Ireland and England for the first time in decades.
- The Irish Prime Minister John Bruton said on Tuesday he would be happy to meet Sinn Fein again once they agree to play by the rules.
- Working nurses along with their union representatives are to be given a place on the proposed Commission on Nursing aimed at persuading the profession from voting for a strike.
- The last of the big six global PC manufacturers has decided to locate in Ireland with Tuesday's announcement of a 10 million Irish pound investment by the Compaq Computer Corporation.
